curriculumTitle: Alley Cats STEM Academy: Applied Physics & Geometry (Refined Micro-Modules)
overview: A rigorous, experiential learning curriculum situated in a 'living laboratory' environment (Bowling, Mini-Golf, Arcade). This curriculum is specifically designed for DOE TRIO programs to ensure strict separation between entertainment and education. It utilizes 21 distinct micro-activities to satisfy HEA requirements for instruction in mathematics and science. Students engage in data acquisition, statistical analysis, and geometric modeling using high-interest mechanics.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I; concurrent enrollment or completion of high school Physical Science or Physics recommended.

fieldTrips.name: Alley Cats Entertainment
fieldTrips.description: A multi-attraction venue housing bowling lanes, miniature golf courses, and an arcade. The venue serves as the physics laboratory for this curriculum.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: The facility provides the necessary apparatus (lanes, inclined planes, projectile launchers) to conduct kinematics and geometry experiments that cannot be replicated in a standard classroom.

activities.title: Bowling Module 1: The Need for Speed (Kinematics)
activities.description: Students utilize the bowling lane as a friction-variable track to calculate average velocity, differentiating between the oil pattern (slide) and the dry backend (roll).
learningObjectives: Measure time accurately using digital stopwatches.
Calculate average velocity using v = d/t.
Convert units from feet/second to meters/second.
teks: Physics 4(B): Describe and analyze motion in one dimension using equations.
Physics 2(E): Design and implement investigative procedures.
texasStemStandards: STEM Skills: Data acquisition and measurement.
STEM Content: Application of scientific laws.

detailed: Explain that the distance from the foul line to the head pin is exactly 60 feet.
Instruct students to convert 60 feet to meters (approx 18.28m) before calculation.
Ensure students differentiate between the time the ball is released and when it crosses the foul line.

brief: Time from foul line to impact.
detailed: Designate one timer and one recorder per roll.
Roll the ball attempting to keep it on the lane.
Record the time elapsed from the moment the ball crosses the foul line until it hits the pins.
Calculate Velocity (v) = 18.28m / Time (s).
Average the velocity of three distinct rolls.

trioCompliance.justification: Provides rigorous laboratory science instruction mandated by the HEA. Cost of bowling is allowable as a facility rental fee for educational purposes.
heaRequirements: Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in mathematics and science

activities.title: Bowling Module 2: Heavy Hitters (Momentum & Energy)
activities.description: Students analyze the relationship between mass and momentum by using bowling balls of varying weights (8lb vs 14lb) to observe impact force and pin scatter.
teks: Physics 6(C): Calculate the mechanical energy of, power generated within, and momentum of a physical system.
Physics 6(D): Demonstrate and apply the laws of conservation of energy and momentum.
texasStemStandards: STEM Fluency: Critical Thinking and Problem Solving.

detailed: Instruct students to find a 'Light' ball (6-8lbs) and a 'Heavy' ball (12-14lbs).
Remind students that mass must be converted from lbs to kg (1 lb = 0.453 kg).
Ask students to attempt to throw both balls at the same speed.

brief: Weigh balls and convert to kg.
detailed: Record the mass of Ball A and Ball B in kg.
Roll Ball A and use previous timing method to determine velocity.
Calculate Momentum (p) = mass * velocity.
Repeat for Ball B.
Qualitatively describe the sound and pin scatter difference between the two balls.

trioCompliance.justification: Direct application of Newton's laws and conservation of momentum.

activities.title: Bowling Module 3: Coefficient of Friction
activities.description: Students calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the bowling ball and the oiled lane surface by observing deceleration.
teks: Physics 4(D): Calculate the effect of forces on objects, including friction.
Physics 4(F): Identify and describe motion relative to different frames of reference.

detailed: The lane is oiled heavily in the first 40ft and dry in the back 20ft.
Have students time the ball for the first half of the lane and the second half.
Use the difference in velocity to find deceleration (a).
Use F=ma and F_f = mu*N to solve for mu.
Set up two timers: one for 0-30ft mark, one for 30-60ft mark.
Calculate v1 (initial) and v2 (final).
Calculate acceleration a = (v2 - v1) / t.
Assuming flat lane, a = -mu * g. Solve for mu.

trioCompliance.justification: Advanced physics concepts involving forces and tribology.

activities.title: Bowling Module 4: Rotational Energy (Spin)
activities.description: Students estimate the angular velocity (RPM) of a bowling ball to calculate its rotational kinetic energy compared to its translational kinetic energy.
learningObjectives: Discuss moment of inertia for a solid sphere.
teks: Physics 5(B): Describe and analyze motion in one dimension using equations (extended to rotational).
Physics 6(D): Conservation of Energy.

brief: Place tape on ball for visibility.
detailed: Use a piece of contrasting tape on the finger holes.
Film the ball rolling down the lane.
Count how many full rotations occur in 1 second.
Convert Rotations Per Second to Radians Per Second.
Review video to count rotations (N) in time (t).
Calculate w = 2 * pi * (N/t).
Assume ball is a solid sphere (I = 0.4 * m * r^2).
Calculate Rotational KE = 0.5 * I * w^2.

trioCompliance.justification: Application of rotational mechanics and energy conservation.

activities.title: Bowling Module 5: Acoustic Physics (Speed of Sound)
activities.description: Students measure the delay between seeing the pins hit and hearing the crash to calculate the speed of sound.
learningObjectives: Calculate speed of sound in air.
Understand the difference between light speed (instant) and sound speed.
teks: Physics 7(A): Examine and describe oscillatory motion and wave propagation.
Physics 7(B): Investigate and analyze characteristics of waves.

brief: Stand far from the pins (behind settee).
Time visual impact vs auditory arrival.
detailed: The distance needs to be significant (e.g., 80-100ft from pins).
Students watch for the ball hitting pins (start timer).
Students stop timer when they hear the crash.
Discuss human reaction time error vs actual travel time.
Stand as far back as possible.
Start timer when you SEE the impact.
Stop timer when you HEAR the impact.
Calculate Speed = Distance / Time.
Calculate percent error against standard speed of sound (343 m/s).

trioCompliance.justification: Wave physics and experimental error analysis.

activities.title: Bowling Module 6: Probability of the Spare
activities.description: Students record the remaining pin configurations (leaves) after the first ball to calculate the empirical probability of common spares (e.g., the 10-pin, 7-pin).
teks: Statistics 5(A): Determine the probability of an event.
Statistics 2(A): Analyze data sets.

detailed: Teach the numbering of the pin pyramid (1 is head pin, 7 and 10 are back corners).
Have students record exactly which pins stand after the first throw.
Aggregate class data to find the most common 'leave'.
For every frame where a strike is not thrown, draw the remaining pins.
Count how many times the 7-pin or 10-pin remained.
Probability = (Specific Leave Occurrences) / (Total Non-Strike Throws).
Compare with professional PBA statistics.

trioCompliance.justification: Introductory statistics and probability data collection.

activities.title: Bowling Module 7: Biomechanics of the Swing
activities.description: Students model the arm as a pendulum to analyze period and frequency, discussing how arm length affects swing time.
learningObjectives: Compare theoretical period to actual swing time.
teks: Physics 7(A): Period of a pendulum.
Anatomy & Physiology 6(A): Biomechanics.

brief: Measure student arm length (shoulder to ball).
detailed: Model the bowler's arm as a simple pendulum.
Measure length L in meters.
Calculate theoretical Period T.
Have student swing arm naturally and time it.
Discuss why muscles (torque) make it different from a free pendulum.
Measure from shoulder pivot to center of hand.
Use T = 2*pi*sqrt(L/9.8).
Perform a relaxed swing and time the full cycle.
Explain why the actual swing might be faster (muscular force).

activities.title: Golf Module 1: The Slope of the Green
activities.description: Students apply the concept of 'rise over run' to calculate the slope of inclined putting surfaces, simulating civil engineering surveying techniques.
learningObjectives: Calculate slope using algebraic methods (m = rise/run).
Measure vertical rise and horizontal run in a real-world setting.
teks: Geometry 2(B): Derive and use the distance, slope, and midpoint formulas.
Geometry 5(A): Investigate patterns to make conjectures about geometric relationships.
texasStemStandards: STEM Skills: Measurement and Data Analysis.

brief: Locate a hole with a clear incline.
detailed: Select a hole where the cup is significantly higher than the tee.
Show students how to measure 'run' (horizontal distance) along the ground.
Show students how to estimate 'rise' by holding a ruler vertical at the hole and sighting from the tee level.
Use the tape measure to find the distance from the start of the slope to the top.
Measure the vertical height of the hill.
Divide the Rise by the Run to get the slope (m).
Express the slope as a percentage (grade).

trioCompliance.justification: Application of Geometry and Algebra II concepts in a field setting.

activities.title: Golf Module 2: The Law of Reflection (Bank Shots)
activities.description: Students use the geometric properties of reflection to predict the path of a golf ball banking off a wall, proving angle of incidence equals angle of reflection.
learningObjectives: Visualize the 'virtual image' or 'phantom hole' concept used in billiards and optics.
teks: Geometry 4(B): Concepts of reflection and symmetry.
Physics 7(D): Characteristics and behaviors of waves (reflection).

brief: Identify a hole requiring a bank shot.
Explain the wall is a mirror line.
Guide students to find the reflection point.
detailed: Explain that the wall acts like a mirror.
Teach the 'Phantom Hole' method: Visualize the hole equidistant behind the wall.
Have students aim for the phantom hole to achieve the correct reflection angle.
Sketch the wall, the ball, and the hole.
Draw a line from the ball to the wall (Incidence).
Measure the angle relative to the wall normal (90 degrees).
Predict the Angle of Reflection.
Putt the ball and see if the physical result matches the geometric prediction.

activities.title: Golf Module 3: Centripetal Force
activities.description: Students analyze a curved putting path (or loop) to understand the centripetal force required to keep the ball on track without slipping.
teks: Physics 4(C): Analyze motion in two dimensions, including circular motion.
Physics 4(D): Calculate effect of forces (Centripetal).

detailed: Have students approximate the radius of the turn using string.
Discuss that friction provides the centripetal force.
If velocity is too high, F_friction < mv^2/r, and the ball flies off.
Measure the radius (r) of the curve.
Putt slowly: does it hold the curve?
Putt fast: does it break the curve?
Explain the relationship between velocity and required force.

activities.title: Golf Module 4: Impulse & Momentum
activities.description: Students investigate the relationship between the force of the putter stroke, the time of contact, and the resulting velocity of the ball.
learningObjectives: Relate Impulse to change in momentum.
teks: Physics 6(C): Momentum and Impulse.
Physics 6(D): Conservation laws.

detailed: Show that a short 'tap' has small t, requiring large F for same velocity.
Show that a 'follow through' increases t, allowing smaller F for smooth control.
Discuss why follow through is taught in sports.
Attempt to hit the ball the same distance using a 'jab' (short t) and a 'sweep' (long t).
Observe which is more consistent.
Explain using Impulse = Force x Time.

activities.title: Golf Module 5: Periodic Motion (Timing Obstacles)
activities.description: Students calculate the period and frequency of moving obstacles (windmills, doors) to mathematically determine the optimal window for putting.
teks: Physics 7(A): Oscillatory motion.
Algebra I 12(A): Functions.

detailed: Identify an obstacle that opens and closes or rotates.
Have students time 10 cycles and divide by 10 for average Period (T).
Determine the 'Open' duration vs 'Closed' duration.
Start timer when obstacle opens, count 10 cycles, stop.
Average Time = Total Time / 10.
Calculate Frequency (f) = 1/T.
If the ball takes 2 seconds to reach the hole, when must you launch relative to the cycle?

activities.title: Golf Module 6: Vector Addition
activities.description: Students break down a complex putt (across a slope) into x (forward) and y (slope/gravity) vector components to determine the aim point.
learningObjectives: Add velocity vector and gravity vector.
teks: Physics 4(C): Vector addition.
Pre-Calculus 4(A): Add and subtract vectors.

detailed: The ball has a forward velocity vector provided by the putter.
Gravity provides a sideways acceleration vector (down slope).
Students must aim 'up slope' so the resultant vector points to the hole.
Visualize the grid on the green.
If gravity pulls the ball 2 units left, you must aim 2 units right.
Draw the vector diagram showing Aim + Gravity = Target.

activities.title: Golf Module 7: Friction & Deceleration
activities.description: Students compare the rolling distance of a ball on the 'green' (turf) vs the 'rough' (carpet/bricks) to analyze different friction coefficients.
teks: Physics 4(D): Friction forces.
IPC 4(D): Investigate effects of forces.

detailed: Have students try to use the same swing strength on the smooth turf and the rough boundary.
Measure how far the ball rolls on each.
Discuss why the rough stops it sooner (higher mu).
Perform 3 trials on the smooth green.
Perform 3 trials on the rough edge/carpet.
Calculate average distance for each.
Calculate ratio of distances.

activities.title: Arcade Module 1: Expected Value (Skeeball Statistics)
activities.description: Students collect data on scoring probabilities in Skeeball to calculate the Expected Value (EV) of a single throw, analyzing risk vs. reward strategies.
learningObjectives: Analyze risk vs reward in a closed system.
teks: Statistics 2(D): Calculate the mean and variance of a discrete random variable.
Statistics 5(B): Evaluate the effectiveness of different strategies.

detailed: Review the formula EV = Sum(Probability * Value).
Ask students to throw 9 balls aiming only for the '40' ring and record hits/misses.
Ask students to throw 9 balls aiming only for the '100' ring and record hits/misses.
Have them calculate which strategy yields the higher average score.
Record your total score when aiming for the safe target (40).
Record your total score when aiming for the risky target (100).
Calculate the experimental probability of hitting the 100 (Hits / Total Throws).
Multiply Probability * 100 to get the EV per ball.
Determine if the high-risk strategy is mathematically sound.

trioCompliance.justification: This activity teaches college-level introductory statistics concepts (Expected Value) using a gamified data source. Game credits are allowable as they are essential for data generation.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.403(a) - Necessary for performance of award

activities.title: Arcade Module 2: Basketball Projectile Motion
activities.description: Students use video analysis of arcade basketball shots to trace parabolic curves, identifying the vertex and calculating the quadratic equation of the shot.
learningObjectives: Describe projectile motion as a parabola.
Identify the vertex (h,k) of a flight path.
teks: Physics 4(C): Analyze and describe accelerated motion in two dimensions, including projectile motion.
Algebra II 4(B): Write the equation of a parabola using given attributes.

detailed: Instruct the recording student to stand safely to the side to get a profile view of the shot.
Have the shooter aim for a 'swish' (high arc).
Review the video in slow motion to pause at the peak (vertex) of the ball's flight.
Watch the replay of the shot.
Draw the x/y axis on graph paper, assuming the release point is (0,y).
Mark the highest point the ball reached (Vertex).
Sketch the parabolic curve connecting release, vertex, and hoop.
Discuss: Did a higher arc increase the chance of the ball going in? Why?

activities.title: Arcade Module 3: 2D Momentum (Air Hockey)
activities.description: Students video record air hockey puck collisions to analyze conservation of momentum in two dimensions, observing vector components before and after impact.
learningObjectives: Visualize momentum vectors in x and y.
teks: Physics 6(D): Conservation of momentum in 1D and 2D.
Physics 4(C): Two-dimensional motion.

detailed: Have one student film from directly above the table.
Have students slide one puck into a stationary puck (oblique collision).
Review video to sketch the angle of departure for both pucks.
Capture a clean collision between two pucks.
Sketch the path of Puck A before impact.
Sketch the V-shape paths of Puck A and B after impact.
Ideally, they split at near 90 degrees if elastic. Did they?

activities.title: Arcade Module 4: Human Reaction Time
activities.description: Students use reflex-based arcade games (e.g., Whack-a-Mole or light buttons) to measure neural reaction time and calculate signal transmission speed.
teks: Biology 10(A): Nervous system interactions.
Statistics 2(A): Data analysis.

detailed: Use a game that requires immediate response to visual stimuli.
Explain the path: Eye -> Brain -> Spinal Cord -> Hand.
Discuss why visual reaction is usually ~250ms.
Play the game focusing on speed.
Record your reaction score.
Compare your time to the class average.
Discuss factors affecting reaction (fatigue, focus).

activities.title: Arcade Module 5: Circuits & Logic (Pinball/Pacman)
activities.description: Students observe the input/output systems of arcade cabinets (joysticks, buttons, screens) to diagram the basic logic flow (If/Then) and circuit completion.
teks: Computer Science I 4(B): Algorithms and flowcharts.
Physics 5(F): Electric circuits.

detailed: Pick a simple game (e.g., Pac-Man or Pinball).
Ask: What is the input? (Button press). What is the output? (Flipper moves).
Ask: What is the logic? (IF ball hits bumper THEN add 100 points).
Identify all buttons/sensors (Inputs).
Identify all lights/movements (Outputs).
Draw a flowchart showing: Start -> Input -> Decision -> Output.
Write one 'If/Then' statement representing a game rule.

activities.title: Arcade Module 6: Gear Ratios (Racing Sims)
activities.description: Students utilize racing simulators to observe the relationship between engine RPM and vehicle speed, analyzing the concept of gear ratios and mechanical advantage.
teks: Physics 6(A): Work and power.
Algebra I 3(B): Calculate rate of change.

detailed: In low gear, high RPM = low speed (high torque).
In high gear, low RPM = high speed.
Discuss trade-off between Torque and Speed.
Accelerate to a constant speed (e.g., 40mph).
Observe the tachometer (RPM).
Shift up and observe how RPM drops while speed stays constant.
Explain why 1st gear is for starting (force) and 5th is for cruising.

activities.title: Arcade Module 7: Light & Optics (Gun Games)
activities.description: Students investigate how light-gun games function (using IR sensors or screen flash) to understand line-of-sight and optical calibration.
teks: Physics 7(D): Behavior of light.
Geometry 2(A): Euclidean geometry basics.

detailed: Explain that the gun reads light from the screen (or IR bars).
Have students stand at extreme angles to see if the 'hit' registers.
Discuss triangulation and calibration.
Stand directly in front and fire.
Step 45 degrees to the side and aim at the same spot.
Does the crosshair line up? Why or why not?
Hypothesize how the computer knows where you are pointing.
